intro: Huntleya imbricata, commonly known as the sand verbena, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a low-growing perennial with a mat-forming habit, characterized by its narrow, fleshy leaves and showy, five-petaled flowers. The plant thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, often found in desert and semi-arid environments. Its flowers, which range in color from white to pink, bloom in late spring to early summer. Huntleya imbricata is adapted to harsh conditions, making it a resilient species in its native habitat.
